title: 108_hr2669
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Model Alternative Publicly Accountable Schools Act of 2003". The District of Columbia is a national model for public charter schools, with the largest number per capita in the nation. Despite limited facilities, these schools have been successful and in high demand, leading to extensive waitlists for admission. Low-performing schools are designated as transformation schools, receiving increased resources and specialized attention. The District of Columbia is setting a model for public charter schools by designating low-performing schools as transformation schools, providing increased resources and specialized attention to improve the performance of low-income and other children. This approach should be encouraged and developed as a model for other school districts to offer public school alternatives similar to targeted assistance schools. The District of Columbia is setting a model for public charter schools by designating low-performing schools as transformation schools, providing increased resources to improve the performance of low-income and other children. These resources are available to targeted assistance schools and charter schools under specific sections of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The purposes of this Act are to provide a model for school districts in the United States, based on the experience of the District of Columbia, by establishing fully accountable public alternatives to traditional public schools. This includes public transformation schools for low-income children and public charter schools for parents who choose them. Expansion of opportunities for low-income parents in D.C. to enroll their children in higher-performing schools. Public Transformation Schools in the District of Columbia are allocated $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and additional funds for the next 4 years to enhance student opportunities and improve school performance. These schools are designated by the Superintendent of the District of Columbia Public Schools. The Direct Loan Fund for Charter School Improvement in the District of Columbia is allocated $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and additional funds for the following 4 years to expand opportunities for students to attend public charter schools in the District. Any authorization of appropriations under this section is in addition to any other authorizations available for the purposes of this Act. SEC. 5. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR SCHOOLS RECEIVING ASSISTANCE.

The State Education Agency for the District of Columbia must submit an annual progress report to Congress, the Mayor, and City Council on public transformation and charter schools receiving funds under this Act.

SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for the following 4 years.
